title: Part (a)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not accurately include either of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes the first criterion below, but not the second.
The response accurately includes both of the criteria below.

title: Part (b)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response should be consistent with point X shown on the graph in part (a).
descriptions: The response does not state that the expected inflation rate is greater than the actual inflation rate.
The response states that the expected inflation rate is greater than the actual inflation rate.

title: Part (c)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response should be consistent with the answer to part (b).

The response must both state no and explain why in order to receive the point.
descriptions: The response does not state that no, borrowers on fixed-rate loans will not benefit from the expected inflation rate being higher than the actual inflation rate and/or does not explain that this is because they will pay a higher real interest rate.

The response states that no, borrowers on fixed-rate loans will not benefit from the expected inflation rate being higher than the actual inflation rate because they will pay a higher real interest rate.

title: Part (d)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response must both state that the government budget will move into deficit and explain why in order to receive the point.
descriptions: The response does not state that the government budget will move into deficit and/or does not explain that automatic stabilizers such as transfer payments and progressive income taxes will increase government spending and decrease government revenues.

The response states that the government budget will move into deficit and explains that automatic stabilizers such as transfer payments and progressive income-taxes will increase government spending and decrease government revenues.

title: Part (e)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response shows a leftward shift of the SRPC MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaae4uaiaabkfacaqGqbGaae4qaaaa@3939@ (see below).

title: Part (f)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the national debt will increase.
The response states that the national debt will increase.

title: Part (g)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response should be consistent with the change in the national debt identified in part (f).
descriptions: The response does not accurately include either of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes the first criterion below, but not the second.
The response accurately includes both of the criteria below.

title: Part (h)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response should be consistent with the change in the equilibrium real interest rate shown in part (g).

The response must both state that economic growth will slow in the long run and explain why – linking the change in the equilibrium real interest rate to a change in investment in physical capital – in order to receive the point.
descriptions: The response does not state that the country’s economic growth will slow in the long run and/or does not explain that an increase in real interest rates will increase the cost of borrowing, which decreases investment spending on plant and equipment and reduces capital formation.

The response states that the country’s economic growth will slow in the long run and explains that an increase in real interest rates will increase the cost of borrowing, which decreases investment spending on plant and equipment and reduces capital formation.
